awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description:  This project is focused on investigating new quantum material properties that are provoked when two materials with dissimilar properties, such as, semiconductor and ferroelectric materials, are coupled together. One may expect to find the resulting material properties to be the sum of the properties of each material. However, this situation changes when the layers of each material are only a few atoms thick, creating a quantum interface material. For example, whereas short-range bonding between atoms dominates the material properties of semiconductors, in ferroelectrics the bonding between atoms is predominantly long-range. Combining the two materials at one interface creates a hybrid bonding that forms exciting new quantum material functionalities. The polarization in the ferroelectric oxide allows tuning and controlling the semiconductor electronic and optical properties for smaller and faster electronics. Likewise, mobile charges in the semiconductor is exploited to affect the polarization in the ferroelectric, creating the opportunity for smaller and faster memory storage devices. Basically, the interface is a "new quantum material" that creates new intriguing possibilities to investigate quantum effects, such as the fractional quantum Hall effect, as well as the manipulation of electrons, control of electrical current flow, electron spin, and the material interaction with light. These are the fundamental ingredients for novel scientific and technological opportunities for new discoveries and exciting new products in electronics and photonics. This research provides opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students who bring their excitement to regional middle school classrooms and public places, i.e. Arkansas Shopping Mall, to stimulate inquiry into science education. Recognizing the need for women and minorities in science, recruitment for students is at the annual National Black and Hispanic National meeting and Materials Research Society (MRS) meetings.

Technical description:  The project is investigating the properties of semiconductor-transition metal oxide quantum interfaces at the monolayer scale. The challenge arises mostly because of the difficulty of epitaxial growth with the disparity of structural properties and lattice parameters. This challenge, however, has proven to be very much ideal for the progress made in layer-by-layer growth by molecular beam epitaxy, with in-situ characterization capability for atomic-scale scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy, and piezoelectric force microscopy, and is the approach taken in this proposal. For example, the research team is growing monolayers of: GaAs (001), InGaAs (001) and GaAsP (001) on BaTiO3 (110) and BiFeO3 (110) grown on SrTiO3 (110), to produce transition metal-semiconductor quantum interfaces. For analysis, the team is using scanning tunneling and piezoelectric force microscopy for morphology and spectroscopy to provide real-time data, by providing interactive feedback, needed to understand the interface from single monolayers to 10-20 nm thicknesses. For the interface between dissimilar materials, the team is evaluating the effects of the local density of states, polarization screening, surface reconstruction, electric and magnetic field coupling, bonding between sp-electrons and d-electrons, fractional quantum Hall effect, localization of charge, and lattice match, mismatch and strain on the interface electronic and photonic properties. As a more high-risk exciting opportunity the team is using high quality semiconductor/transition metal oxide and transition metal oxide/semiconductor interfaces, to stack interfaces, to form a superlattice of quantum interfaces with novel properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We developed a new material system to enable monolithic integration of lasers, power amplifiers, modulators, waveguides, detectors, and microwave devices, for RF-THz frequencies, or microwave photonics, on a signal chip. Given that the silicon semiconductor has been the backbone of our economic and military strength, one might think that the best platform for this photonic system is to integrate the laser light source, active optical elements, and the operating electronics all on a silicon chip. However, while silicon has been more than great for electronics, it has been less so for photonics. Silicon is an indirect bandgap semiconductor. Excited electrons in silicon are good for producing current, but not so much for producing light. In fact, 1,000,000 excited electrons in silicon are needed to produce a single photon. By comparison, a similar structure using GaAs only requires 1 to 2 excited electrons to produce one photon.  Despite much effort by the photonics community over a long period of time, a satisfactory silicon laser has not yet been developed, although there does exists promising research reports.

In addition, a photonics option other than a silicon laser, is an InP semiconductor laser, epitaxially grown on a separate InP substrate or bonded directly onto a silicon substrate. This approach has been successful. However, the InP substrate is expensive and a bonded InP laser does come with potential for significant coupling losses and reliability issues causing important consequences for optical power budgets, energy efficiency, and especially cost. Consequently, delivering an efficient laser technology, monolithically integrated with optical and electrical functionality at RF-THz frequencies onto a single chip, and at low cost, has been and remains both a significant challenge and an exciting opportunity.

Intellectual Merit: Our research on this project demonstrated a new material system as an answer to this challenge. Specifically, we explored the monolithic integration of III-V semiconductors on dissimilar substrates of sapphire, BaTiO3 (BTO), and SiC. The growth of GaAs, AlAs, InP, and InGaAs, or III-V semiconductors more generally, on dissimilar substrates must consider two different crystal structures, different chemistries and bonding energies, and a significant lattice mismatch. While this is a significant challenge, it has been ideal for molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). Using MBE, we have fabricated low defect density (106cm-2) III-V semiconductor material and corresponding InGaAs/GaAs QWs on sapphire, barium titanate, and SiC. This creates the opportunity to fabricate and demonstrate monolithic integration of a III-V semiconductor laser, waveguide, and amplifier on these dissimilar substrates. We have observed that sub-monolayer growth produces nanoscale monolayer islands that perform significantly better than corresponding optical devices based on either QWs or quantum dots QDs, as evidenced by the photoluminescence (PL) intensity and bandwidth narrowing described later.

Using expertise in the growth of dissimilar materials at the University of Arkansas, we have achieved the growth of high-quality interfaces between dissimilar materials that resulted in high quality InGaAs semiconductor quantum wells and carrier confined sub-monolayer III-V islands, (defect density ~ 106 cm-2) on the dissimilar substrates of sapphire, BTO, and SiC. As a result, monolithic integration of RF electronics and III-V photonics on the same sapphire, BTO, or SiC  substrate, is achievable. The potential is for monolithic integration of laser, amplifier, modulator, detector, and microwave devices, all on a sapphire substrate. Major advantages of integrated microwave photonics (IMWP) over current RF communication systems includes reduced size, weight, propagation loss, and most importantly, orders of magnitude more bandwidth.

Broader Impact - Demonstration of high quality III-V semiconductors on dissimilar substrates opens the door to laser, waveguide, and amplifier on sapphire, when added to the fact that RF electronic devices already prefers sapphire as a substrate, creates the exciting opportunity for the fabrication of microwave photonic chips, a potentially a disruptive technology. We also designed and implemented a NEW education program in Material Science and Engineering to prepare a well-trained diverse workforce of graduate and undergraduate students, that can develop innovations in an exciting growing research and commercial market.
